reviewText:
Early Access Review

UPDATE:
-The game is now free to play and those who payed for the game will recive a gift in game.
-I have to give credit where credit is due and say that I'm very happy with how the dev is very active in the community and that they are listening to the consumers.
-From what I understand, there are still Micro-transactions in the game so take that as you will.

-So, why is this still negative? I can honestly say that the pricing wasn't my only issue with the game when reviewing it the first time. The way the game played, lack of customization, never running into people who spoke the same language, and the fact the game resembled that of a mobile port were also problems for me.
-With that being said, I haven't played since my original review and will update this after I get the chance to play again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Early Access Review.
Game is not even close to being playable.
I can not recommend anyone playing this one until a lot of work is done on it.
Game attempts to be a Eve online clone, or from what I could do it will be.
Step 1 create a character, oh and by the way we will need an email address to do that even though we are coming in through steam.
Nothing available except for the 3 race choices, okay ??? so what do they do, what makes them different from each other ??? who knows.
Then you pick the type of character you want to be??  Is this a first person shooter or a space mmo??  Pick sniper, trooper, medic or tank.  I would have preferred you can pick your spaceship and customize with modules instead.
You jump into the game and have the music blaring in your ear, should have the settings before you do that.  No way to change it before hand.
Step 2 create a companion??  well guess what the tutorial does not really do anything to help you out with that.  If you have not played Eve online you don't even have any idea it wants you to make a drone.  So lucky for me I have and go to the cargo bay and make a drone using a kit.
Step 3 fly to space.
Okay I guess I don't really have any say in my ship or what it does or what weapons I have or cargo or nothing.
Find the action option menu and fly into space and crash to destop.
The game crashes so hard it locks up my pc and I need to do a hard reboot.
Try again, this time I have the tutorial tell me to rotate the camera, no instructions, no key binding nothing.  Lucky for me I have played Eve online so I manage to do that.  Then the game crashes again.  Crashes so hard again I need to do a hard reboot.

Unistall game, hope they do not close the server since they can not even afford to keep the game up and running while under development.

Game has potential if they work on it and get people to give them money for this.
Since I can not even fly in space yet they won't be getting any money from me.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

(Disclaimer - Game was originally won via Steamgifts from before the game went F2P)

-Poor account security. Passwords aren't encrypted in the games servers, and a recovery request gets them sent back to you in plain text. By far, this is the weakest form of account security that a multiplayer-mmo could have. (Update - SS of what you get when you put in a recovery request. No confirmation required, not even a simple security question. Just them pulling user info from what is, from the devs own admission a unencrypted user database and sending it right out - http://i.imgur.com/C9U2Rdq.png )

-Smatterings of untranslated text. The account recovery screen for one has been left in Russian, while most other account pages have been translated.

-Race selection. One of the race descriptions completely overshot the description screen. so you're unable to read a segment of it.

-Ship selection. The ship selection screen has a section where you can see your ship, yet quite a few ships clip through the screen. That said, the ships themselves are beautifully designed, as are the character cards. That said, the ship descriptions are spotty, having been translated to English but not properly localized. (Case in point, housing durability? What? Oh, HULL durability.)

-Micro-transactions. This game has em, despite the games kickstarter and official reviews saying that the game wouldn't have em.

-Extremely, EXTREMELY, variable pricing. The game launched at $5, a month ago with a small discount to 4.49. The games price was then jacked up to $10 on the 18th - Two weeks after launching. The game was then dropped down to $5 two days later on the 20th. And THEN (Yes, it continues...) the games price was set to $1 (Note - The game DIDN'T get a discount set, the games base price itself was lowered) on the 28th. (See last point for another bit about 'variable pricing'

And now we come to this month. The games price was jacked up to $15 on the 2nd. (Price history available here - https://steamdb.info/app/368750/)

Also, see my disclaimer? About getting this at Steamgifts? Yeah. The dev has been putting up quite a few copies - my guess, in hopes of getting positive reviews and to try and get more players - of this game their in recent weeks. (Just today he'd put up 129 copies)

Speaking of players, the game had lost quite a few of them which is what lead to the giveaway flood. The game topped out at 3600 owners on the 2nd, and by the 8th the owner count fell down to 2460 (Losing almost 1200 owners). Oddly enough, that tanking happened right after the games base price rose from $1 to $15, so I guess many people thought something looked very off about that drastic a price jump. (Owner stats available here - https://steamdb.info/app/368750/graphs/)

-Incoming bundle flood. The Dev stated that 25k keys were given out to various bundlers and game websites. One month after release, and everyone and their grandmother will be bundling it.

UPD - Flood is mostly over, for what good it did. Stillborn from the start, the game topped out at 19 players in the past week. The dev was a bit quick to make such a big deal about the game hitting just under 1k players after their little bundle flood, since he'd confused card idlers with actual players.

-Extremely overstating given reviews. From what the dev said about the PCGamer review, you'd THINK that they called this one of the 'best games in 2016'... But they didn't.

-Available for Free elsewhere. Yeah. Facebook and Android.

Honestly? Just wait for the bundles to be released. Or take advantage of one of the free EA versions.

And after 'consulting the fans', the game has went F2P. I don't see why the Devs are making such a big hoopla about going F2P when the game was advertised as a F2P game in the first place. I guess you could tack this on under the variable pricing as well.

...Speaking of the F2P update, this doesn't exactly bode well for the 'cash shop' that many of this games official reviews say the game doesn't have. Supposed to have been removed two updates ago, as STATED by the dev, all we've gotten since then was a mention that it'll be 'updated next patch' and that next patch has just come out with... no mention of it, at all.

As an Early Access game that was only $5 I am thrilled with this little gem of a Space MMO RPG. If this Genre of game interests you then please take the time to read this review.

The short of it.

This game has come to PC and other platforms from facebook and app status" - it is being remodelled and improved for us as we speak and has enormous potential to steal you away from reality.

- 3 Races to choose from. Humans
date: Borguzands and Kriptizids.\n\n- A Variety of classes / ship types to pilot
recommended: each with their own unique abilities. Sniper
voteText: Engineer and Trooper\n\n- A shared bank facility for your characters
helpfulPercent:
even across races.

- An auction house for the budding traders amongst us.

- Crafting of modules for your ship with randomized stats and bonus abilities providing you with an almost unlimited number of builds to aim towards and test at your leisure.

- Mining either with your ship
votesHelpful: up close and personal with the asteroids to collect ores or by placing Mining stations in the contested sectors to collect nebula elements for your passive skills.\n\n- PVP / PVE yes this game is not always safe

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So let me start off by saying I'd say this game is 'okay' at this stage and by 'okay' I mean on a scale of 1 - 10 , it'd be around '6'.

I got this as it was free-to-play and since this game is still in early access, from my experience it's still rough around the edges, very rough around the edges!.

I gave this a positive review (although I'm in two minds about it) as I think it deserves a chance, especially since it's free-to-play, not really a bad game (just needs some improvisation/improvements)
and it seems the devs are really listening to the players.
For some reason this game reminds me of X-Rebirth (minus the customization's, scope and the quality)

Looking at the Pros :-
The game does seem to have some depth to it, which is good.
The Dev's are really trying to improve this game and listening to the players.
The graphics are'okay-ish', for some reason I couldn't select any other preset other than 'fastest'.
The gameplay is decent and at times really engaging with 3 factions to choose from.
There's quite a lot of stuff to do in-game and the world map is pretty big.

Onto the Cons:-
Virtually non-existant tutorial except for a few image's showing what the icon's on-screen do.
The UI really needs to be redone, it's an eye-sore at times and difficult to navigate.
The music in-game is repetitive to the point I got fed up with it within around 30 mins.
The controls need an overhaul since it's abit hard to understand, atleast make 'W' and 'S', 'Thrust' and 'Reverse'.
Micro-transactions, feel like pay-to-win. (Not really a con since the devs need to make money from somewhere).
Didn't meet any other player (seems like not many are playing this as of yet).

This game really has potential but is not finding it as of yet, with time and the if improvements are added by the devs in the future, this game will be a really good game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Nothing personal to the development team.

My early access opinion.  The game feels like Star Fox meets Dark Orbit.  Just think of it as a 3d Dark Orbit but with bad controls and less depth.


Pros:

It's a Free to Play space game


Cons:

Bad english translations
The game has no depth.  There's no story and no good quest.
The tutorial is a headache.  It constantly spams you with tips.  It goes overboard.
The UI is bad.  It's very generic and in the way.  The HUD suffers from the same problem.
The controls are the worst part of the game.
There is no open universe feel to the game.  It's just very small zones connected by a quick warp animations.  Each zone is basically the same.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nGreat game concept but has horrid and very simplistic gameplay.  The ship flight controls were designed for a two button controller with a joy stick but there is no joy.  You have NO true control over your ship especially considering all that could be done with keyboard controls.   It is more like hurling a rock in space than navigating a vehicle.   The dashboard of information about your ship, your speed, your enemy, other target is very simple and updates come very, very slow.  Immediate game feedback is an absolute and this game has none.  Lag was built into the game and we all hate lag.  I can only believe this game was NOT designed for PC gamers but had simplistic gaming platforms in mind.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

At first it was hard to comment on something I just could not access, I know its early release n' all , but I should've realisied that flaws in a log in process would set the scene for a frustrating experience. The first minute of game time doesn't capture the pain of creating an account with no visible cursor, entry field or tab control to guide its completion. Once created (like working in brail) and logged in, the sound cut in to assail the eardrums and a static screen materialised but failed to progress into movement of a game, just 2.3gb of space I was going to leave for sometime before trying again. However, curiosity got the better of me and I tried again until I got it working ...hmmm think I found out what killed the cat. Still, I stuck it out for 3 hours to poke around  but it currently has too many Cons for me to recommend just yet.
Cons.
Major action is performed by way of mouse controlled clicks on a series of icons that form a large and restrictive overlay down the left hand side of the screen: icons include one for weapons fire and 2 for ship speeds, which if your used to simultanous play of left click and WASZ motion are very stilted/don't flow. The overlay also renders part of the screen unusable for  other controls like identification by click of ships or structures that pass underneath and changes of camera angle by mouse rotation and I could not reduce it because this drives the game. The method of control clearly does not allow personalisation of key binding as there is none!.
Other actions use a drop down menu that was hit and miss to trigger and really only worked in my home galaxy. So things like triggering the map to find a way back ,  locate items or check ships hold were none existnant anywhere else.

There is also very little guidance on basic operations or strategies of the game and what help there is consisted of a newby tab that when active presents a series of prompt orientationed tasks so out of step with learning they just don't match requirements for teaching and you must complete these task in turn to move them on. There are also comments about controlling  passive skills and getting close to planet surfaces, but I just could not get close to any planet I just passed through them and nothing triggered.

It is surposed to be MMO and one of the newby tasks tells you to form a group but I just could not get the drop down menu to appear  to allow this to be done and could not progress any further on the help tasks as a result.

Mixed:

Yes, it look like its wriiten in Russian and some of wording is in an odd pidgeon but it can be followed.
The graphic aren't brilliant but its in alpha afterall.
The map suggests there could be a significant number of systems and planets to explore but I  found the current game play available to me somewhat repetative.

Pro:
Having the choice of 3 factions that control various sectors of space, with base turrets and stations suggests that with development, more people and a better understaning of what to do the game may actually contain elements of strategy and co-op that could be something far better than I found. I just could not find any clear narrative to gave a good insight into these matters, but i did enjoy being attacked while completing boring hunter gather tasks albeit that I had basic skills and little instruction.

Summary: Overall although I will not delete it from my system just yet, I would not have spent the time and effort to download, create a login id and play had I known just what it was like at this time. It is someway behind fractured space, the other Alpha space game I have on steam, but there may be added dimensions to this game in time that I am currently missing, we will see

Update 1:  Must at least have something going for it as I have come back today to have another look today despite saying I'd leave it a while. I have now managed to find a discussion thread about 2 keys, W is for forward when pressed once and pressed a second time for stop (but not for accelerate, that's another icon  click ) and M does trigger the map even when the drop down action menu doesn't, but simple things like this are just not shown in the game. I am also now having problems understanding when things like extra ship modules are activiated or not because there is no positive flag or change in external visual appearance and it's unclear from all the differenet stats given whether suggested changes in ability are as a result of them being activated or deactivated unless you understand all the developer 's logic  which at this stage I do not.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Free to play shoddy rip off of EVE online

While a number of the things that made EVE great have been partially transfered over to this game, it's already dead on the english side it seems, at least for the human race which is somehow still the dominating race which controls most of the center zone.  Found one person online and they stopped talking after I asked if they could help me with the starting missions.

Good things:
+ Interesting open world space with simplistic (if slightly buggy) click to point in that direction controls
+ nice in game music (which later becomes a bad thing because it gets VERY repeatative
+ Cool ship customization idea (though I haven't been able to see if the higher level modules are just reskins of old modules)
+ Moderately interesting subfaction lore (at least on the human side).  Apparently things are set up in a sort of democratic caste system that is separated into workshops" based on 4 ways to superiority: Fire power
hoursPlayed:
and regeneration

Bad things:
-- Little to no player base  (if they are out there
voteText: they aren't talking to me
helpfulPercent: and from the brief interaction I had
votesHelpful: it really doesn't sound like they are out there)\n- EVE's semicrap passive skill system.  Get the required things to get that passive skill (like the ability to use certian things) and then place it on a timer.  There is also a second skill system that seems to be based on modules that your ship has but I have no idea how to get that to work.  this second one just gives you stat buffs it seems.\n- Poor UI management: While one side of the screen is nice with windows and menus you can collapse to move out of the way for better control of your environment
votesTotal: they seem to have forgotten to do that to the other side of the screen.  The quests alone seem to take up half the screen and can't really be clicked behind because a tool tip pops up then that basically just rewords what the quest says
votesFunny:
not always helpful.
- Various other things half clutter the other side of the quest log which is probably the reason the quest log is pushed out towards the middle of the screen.
- poor instructions and tutorials:  often times I struggled with understanding what they meant or will find that I might have already been doing that.  Occasionally I'm meant to basically repeat previous actions and get results that wern't the same as before because the tutorial didn't want to show you what else you would get from those things at that time but now it wants to show you that you could also get other things with the same activities in a different mission.

Honestly
commentsCount: I'm not sure this game can be saved right now.  It will need an overhaul and a "rerelease" to draw in a nee before you could even call it a B list game."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

An interesting, ambitious game with a lot of potential. While there are certainly a lot of things that could be improved on - faulty, difficult and confusing controls and the lack of clear instructions and guides for new players being it's biggest sins - Nebula Online is a fairly decent game. It's not revolutionary or mindblowing per se, but it's certainly promising and interesting.

However, the developers need to start focusing on improving and patching the game's biggest and most fatal flaws instead of expanding the game and making it bigger than it already is. I feel like this game is way too ambitious; it has more than it's developers could handle. It's recommendable for them not to add any new features to the game and focus on working on the ones it already has. Remember - if you chase two rabbits, you lose them both.
voteText: 18 of 30 people (60%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Immediate change of UI for Computer Players.
Needs Better Textures.
Needs more soundtracks.
I like the vastness of the map!

I would recommend to stop Cross-Platform and make it only for Computers or Consoles.

Needs Quest Lines as well. (A background story or so).

Its Early Acess so if you pinpoint these it can turn out to be a good game.

Last but not least, every games goal that features MMORPG Sci-Fi experience is to reach EVE Online the mother of all these games in my opinion.

So to do that you will have to stop cross platform, or make part of this game playable in Tablets/Phones
and focus on upgrading the game for Computer Users.

There are lots of things to be done and lots of time too.
This game does have a future, we will see soon.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is quite easy to learn and you got a good tutorial at the beginning. The tutorial was very short but i was able to play the game, go mining, fighting, crafting, and so on.

The next good thing would be the speed of troubleshooting. There appeared an ingame bug, which made it impossible to buy or sell anything. They fixed it within 2 hours on a sunday.

But why was i dissapointed?
Grafics? They are ok, the game is still in development.
Promises: i will cite the description: Create your unique ship
recommended: explore space together with your friends. "\nCreate your unique ship: you will find a short instruduction on the website
hoursPlayed: that you can build your own special ship by moduls. so what happend? When you create a new character
voteText: you will choose the class. From now on
helpfulPercent:
you have your ship with 6 modules. You can replace each module by an other module of the same type. You will change some stats of your ship. Its like change your boots or sword in a common role-play-game by some better boots or a better sword. This is the part what they call "Create your unique ship". Skills are only related to your selected class.

Obtain resources: there are different recources which need different things to obtain. Gathering resources is very ineffective at the moment. But the game is still in development. So it might change.

Crafting: You get from your enemys something like blueprints. You can go to any station and build it. All you know
votesHelpful: is the level of the item and how many resources you need. But you never know what type of item you will get. Will it be a weapon? Something for movement? It will be always a surprise :P\nits ok
votesTotal: if they dont write the detail of the item with stats and so on
votesFunny:
but to write what kind of item it will become would be great.

Conclusion
The lack of opportunities can still be closed by further development. The promise to create your own unique ship and have no real feature to do so is just the wrong way. Combined with very ineffective gathering of resources and a ineffective combat system it has nothing value left in the game."

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nFirst Impressions" review
date: after only about 2 hours according to Steam
recommended:
perhaps only half of that in actual game play.
Based on the "Early Access" version available during the first half of January 2016.

+ Nebula Online runs reasonably well on my 5+ year old gaming laptop.

- Options (audio & video settings) cannot be accessed until after the character creation process.
Would have preferred to turn off the music right away as it was both too loud and not to my taste.

- Steam version only supports full-screen mode currently.  I prefer Windowed mode for a variety of reasons (easier use of a password manager
hoursPlayed: taking notes in a text editor during game play
voteText: and especially keeping an eye on my laptop's GPU heat).\n\n+ They came up with some creative playable races in addition to humans.  Background lore is limited
helpfulPercent: but at least there is a little.\n\n+ On first login
votesHelpful: the interface displays some popup tips as you explore the various sections in the station's interface.\n- Some of them go by too quickly - I'm a slow reader.  Perhaps changing to click-or-tap to close instead of timed messages would be better.\n+ That said
votesTotal: the station interface seems pretty straight forward.\n\n- Although there is newbie help
votesFunny: it didn't seem to explain the actual ship movement & combat.  Or maybe I just missed those details.\n\n- Designed as a mobile app
column16: and there's no key controls/mapping section in the Options
column17:
so figuring out ship movement & combat was more of a challenge than it might have been.
I tried using the typical WASD FPS-style movement keys with only partial success.
W & S tilt the ship up or down rather than acting as Forward & Brake.
A & D do turn the ship left & right.
The ship can also be turned via the mouse
column18: but I've not figured out how to do that consistently yet.\nThere are two "move forward" keys
column19: one with a single arrow and one with a double arrow.\nIt took a while to figure out without tooltips and without a speed indicator on the HUD.\nTurns out the double-arrow icon is for going faster
column20: but can't be used during combat.\nYou can double-click on an enemy to automatically orient your ship towards their current position and start moving towards them.  However
column22: so if they are moving around you will have to keep double-clicking them from time to time
column23:
while also adjusting the camera angle to keep them in view.

- Lost my first NPC battle because I was expecting the attack key to be an auto-attack.  It wasn't clear to me at first that the periodic weapons fire between our ships was only coming from the enemy ship.  No big deal - I know how it works now.

- The non-auto-attack attack button is a pain though.
Its on the quickbar
column24: so you can just press 1 to attack instead of clicking it with the mouse.\nThe mouse is needed for adjusting the camera to keep the enemy in sight
column26: etc.\nThe attack timer is fairly short
column27: so there is a lot of pressing 1 over and over and over
column29: you'll need to either split your attention between the attack timer and ship movements
column30: \nor else spam the 1 key constantly.\nIn either case
column31:
I found it to be uncomfortable for my arm after a while
and needed to relax & stretch my arm from time to time.

- Although designed as a mobile app
column32: its not available yet in Apple's app store.  Would like to try it on my iPad.\n\n- I'm not sure of this yet with my limited experience
column33: but the game seems to be primarily level-based
column34: with equipment also coming into play.  In a PVP MMO
column35: a level-based system typically means there will be some very unbalanced combat between players of different levels
column36: so that's a negative in my book.  I prefer PVP systems where everyone has a chance to take on anyone else
column37:
and the higher levels/ranks give the experienced player more options to choose from but don't make them invincible.

+ Overall the game seems to have a lot to offer.
One can fly or "jump" to different locations within a system
column38: and jump to different linked systems.\nI hear rumors of contested zones
column40: big mining operations on large asteroids
column41: \nand even landing on planets.\nThere is a crafting system for upgrading your ship
column43: etc.\nThey have an auction and a reverse auction.\nIf I can find a way to play without getting a cramp in my arm
column44: I'd like to explore all these things.\nSince this is an Early Access game
column45: I'm hopeful that there will be a lot of interface improvements\nas development progresses.\n- Given the current state of the game (what little I've seen of it so far)
column46: I'd not recommend it (since I have to choose a Yes or a No to submit the review)
column47:
but am hopeful that it will get better in time.  It has a lot of potential.
___________________________________________________________________________
2nd Look - a follow-up to my 1st review:
After several more hours in-game
column48: many of the negatives listed in my previous review seem trivial now.\n\nI've gotten the used to the interface for ship movement & combat as well as the somewhat unusual chat system.  Tried out grouping with others to team up on tough opponents
column49: and even acquired the ability to repair teammates during combat.  Things are looking up
column50: though with all the rough edges I'd still call it an "Early Access" quality game at this point.\n\nTo correct one mistake in my previous review
column51: there's isn't actually a reverse auction.  I misunderstood what I was looking at.  Would be a great feature to add though."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm the first to point out that this is Early Access and that I played it for all of 20 minutes before writing this.

That said, my problems with it are extremely fundamental. If it's being marketed to an English-speaking audience (amongst others), it direly needs someone who speaks English to be doing localization and editing. Hardly the only example, but a good one: when trying to refer to the heading of your ship, one of the 'tutorial' steps says direction of go".

I also realize that instructions and proper walkthroughs are a luxury at early stages of a game
date: but as it is in this current release
recommended: following the steps gets you killed very quickly
hoursPlayed: by landing you in a hopelessly outmatched scenario.\n\nWill I revisit this in a year? Possibly
voteText: I know there are probably a lot of good people putting hard work into this project
helpfulPercent: but from what little I've seen right now
votesHelpful: the writing that went into the setting
votesFunny: and the lack of direction and editing at the foundation level - it all makes me wonder if this will make it out of early access."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Nebula online is a free MMORPG at the star you can choose one of the 3 races and your base spaceship. The idea of this game is explore the universe to get resources for the objective of enhance your spaceship. You can obtain this resources fighting and looting or floting around in the space. Your spaceship can level up and you can build space stations and conquer zones.
Pros:
-The worldbuilding
-The possibilities of building in your spaceship
-The game has achievements
Cons:
-The game is a bit complicated (lack of a real tutorial)
-The controls are a little stiff
In conclusion the game is still in early access and can improve some of the aspects of the game. It looks very promising

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ok OK, yes i know, Some might judge over the fact that I've only played a few minutes, so I can't realy make a point or review here. But, i would like to share me experiences of my first few minutes and how they turned out.

Since I also recieved this game for free, im not one to judge.

So, upon first launch, I recieve a Unity launch window, which in my eyes, was slightly expected, but don't mind it at all. Except, yes, you can choose your resolution, graphics and display AND controls from all in this window. But, the only graphics option is Fastest (ok, I get it, its early access). It doesn't affect me, but this can throw people off since the graphics were good on Fastest, so people with potato PCs might die from it (Just sayin).

In game, it had a nice login screen (altough Im not sure why it can't use our steam ACC as a login already, but im no game dev so idk)and a nice Create screen to create your characters. But when it comes to Tutorials and teaching first time players how to do things in the game, this game lacks that. As a first time player, I read everything it gave me and understood about 40% of it. I still don't understand how to fly (once im in space) and I don't know what my objectives are, as well as how to even check (there is a notifications tab, but there are no markers on the screen).

If I had the ability to give a few bits of feedback, I would say that the game is well made, but there are a few things holding back its potential.

If the game had for example, a window that showed up at the start, after login, saying Do you wish to go through an in depth tutorial?" And you had the option of Yes or No. The tutorial then helps you through the Character setup
date: Main screen and giving you basic directions when in flight. Maybe even a Training course to go around. This will help out first time players
hoursPlayed: who are having trouble with all the controls and different markers and all that. But
voteText: again
votesHelpful: so I can't really take it upon myself to tell people what this game should and shouldn't feature.\n\nThis is just a feedback review
votesTotal: and my first experiences. If im doing anything wrong

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Disclaimer: Got it for free.

Last Update: 26/02/2016 (10 hours after the first review)

-It should have been more mature before a release, EVEN FOR AN EALRY ACCESS GAME.

-‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• interface. <- Slightly improved with the latest updates but well... don't mouse scroll

-The worse controls I have ever seen. Gevs, if you read this, please give us our WASD. <- They did it, they gave us our WASD BUT, the rebind for other keys wasn't added. Also, it's not really intuitive, for people used to classic MMORPGs, W and S should have been for engine and stop engine and the rest of the movement made with the right click of the mouse.

-Hard to take in charge. <- 45 minutes before I finally found ennemies.

-Graphics are correct but could have been improved, even for an MMO, as long as you aren't Blizzard, give use descent graphics.

-Not a lot of active players.

-A quest system could have been added to let us play in solo. <- Added and it's pretty basic but is very nice for a beginning.

Anyway, this game truly have a future.

UPDATE: From what I saw, devs are listening to their players. But don't buy it yet, except if you want to help the game by making feedback.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Buy it, simple as that. It only costs 5 euros, which, for the amount of content you already get, is not enough.

It is still in development, so expect future improvement on graphics, hud, controls, etc..

Devs are active on the forums, asking for players opinions, which is a big difference if we compare it to other bigger games where they claim to be involved with the community, which most of the time is a lie, they are involved with players credit cards! But this one really listens to the fan base.

I saw a post on forums about noobs getting ganked, the next day there was a patch avoiding that. So there you have a little proof about the kind of devs this game has.

This review will be updated over time, but only to thank the developers for bringing such a great idea into a real project.

If you are still not sure because of its early access status, have in mind that the game has been evolving after 3 years of development, we are talking about a company that didnt throw away a project after 3 long years of hard work! This is not the kind of game that doesnt get out of EA. Also, to make it clear, 3 years out of Steam, they didnt come to early access with an alpha that doesnt even launch, or doesnt connect to servers, it is a 100% working game with a lot of content.

To the devs, thank you for bringing this into life. I really hope you get the success you deserve after such a long journey and, again, Mizar Games, I am sorry. See you in the space!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has a few challenges that the average player can not cope with ... there is NO one taking you buy the hand and showing you how to play Nebula Online. You have to work it out for yourself not something most average players can do. 19.8 hrs into the game and I have managed to get to level 3 all because I want to discover this game for myself and how best I can be in the Nebula Online universe.

Would I recomend this gasme to average player ... NO.

Would i recomend this game to a gamer ... YES.

It makes a change from the norm of hit this to auto shoot and go afk. You have to mach the right keys and be in the right place or you die. I have worked out how to do simple things like 'add feinds' just be chatting in local and passing on help to others.

Do not forget this game is very much in alfa, alot of content still to be added. but what there is, is still very playable.

update: More content added with a ingame step-by-step intoduction for the new pilots of Nebula Online.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nYou cannot expect too much on a baby, as well as an early access game. If everything is perfect, it wouldn't be early access anymore. reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAn amusing space simulator that reminds me of Star Conflict but with the MMO feel of Ragnarok Online. Fly around, make friends, harvest resources by clicking on them, and shoot down aggressive NPCs that guard said resources. And it has plenty of flavor text and lore . I look forward to the improvements on the mechanics as development progresses, and the fleshed out story and lore.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For what it is, its decent. Fly around and kill ships for loot. When you get better loot and skills, move on to the next system. Factor in world PvP and territory control and they recently added combat pets (Satelites). If you want to jump into a space shooter, this isn't bad but its also not groundbreaking. I say, support the devs and give it a shot.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nNebula Online - is open world MMO RPG with three different races: Humans, Borguzands, Kriptizids (you can choice for what race you want to play in start of game. I pick Borguzands, because I like more they ship, its looks really better, than in other races). And, of course, game have craft system: you can receive resources from NPC to build your own ship. Its all good things, but lets talk about bad ones. Control and tutorial - this is the worst and unfinished part of the game, as for me. But as Nebula Online in Early Access stage, so developers can fix and and make it more user friendly in any time. Now game is F2P, so can play and test it totally fo free.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Nebula Online more like Rat mining simulator 2016 coming right out of compton hitting the free way right to feels town.

But in all seriousness this game I rate it 8/10 with a possibility of being a 10 if they add some smaller more important up-date/details to the game (Devs are active and working on updates daily and also speak to the comunity Weird right).

Pros- Simple design, but gets harder as you go on.
- Bunch of loot tables for some good RNG fun.
- High Risk High Reward Scenarios. (Dropped a 2000 credit mining station hostile faction shows up aka a real player and kills it, start a fight boys)
- Player driven economy and Player driven leaders.
- Lots of RNG bassed crafting.
- Good Map size for 2gb.
- Backround is beautiful textures can use work.\n-
Cons- High learning curv for flying the ship. (Not to bad if you played other space sims like EVE)
- Missing interactive noobie tutorial (Buts devs are working on one and you can ask other people for help)
- Prices not set yet in auction house but its getting better brand new game people will learn.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A fine game indeed. I look forward to seeing this game furthered in the future. So far I am loving it, and I am ok with the grind now that I can fire two weapons at level 2, and finally reached level 3 recently as the Borguzands which I have to admit their ship design is pretty cool, and the small customizations that come with each piece of equipment really makes my  Rahkgal or however its spelled look pretty wicked. I mean its sad I can't choose how it looks, but its like many MMOs where gear just happens to look different except only weapons drop, and the parts for your ship you have to build with some RNG luck on your side its something you want and something good.

The Auction system is helpful. I have managed to buy some useful parts for my ships from there, and have started selling weapons, and parts to the auction myself to help lower level players. Leveling is difficult at 1, but by the time you reach 2 and add some parts to your ship to get a second weapon it gets alot easier. There appears to be weapons that are... loud? I guess. The first weapon is quiet apparently as it doesn't attract attention, but the second one gets everyone on you, but by that time you should have some decent parts for your ship.

So far its pick race, pick a ship amoung the classes each of the ships look different between race, and function differently. Though I have to admit Borguzand has the coolest ships in the game being all organic like, and their territory is just so... mesmerizing with all those tentacles, bugs, and jellyfish looking things. Although it looks like most go for the other two factions as I don't see many on the Borguzand, and their is only like 3-4 coalitions currently up for them, and less than 50 combined for all those coalitions, but not everyone is in them. Meaning there could be other players not apart of anything at all.

I absolutely recommend this game just to enjoy it now, and get pumped for the future. Sure its Early Access, but that just means more to come in the future, maybe. Some games don't make it, but I hope this one does. I really do.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It has its quirks but it is a pretty decent game. The developers don't have tons of cash but the game shows promise and is slowly being developed. Nothing is better than pulling out and surviving a 4 on 1 battle and then critting the boss...happens rarely but it does happen. Don't get cocky and think that you will harvest the skies...no. Leave that for groups.

And this is the sad part - I wish there were more people playing. So, if you're going to play and you want to enjoy it then you need to bring some one to play with.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Basic Information
Title: Nebula Online
Genre: Free to Play, Indie, Massively Multiplayer, RPG, Early Access
Developer: Mizar Gamer, Komar Games
Publisher: Mizar Games, OtakuMaker.com
Release Date: 5 Jan, 2016

General Impression
Nebula Online seems like a solid MMORPG for the ones who are in this type of genre. From fighting with ships, collecting items, to constant challenging gameplay, this game seems pretty nice. The graphics are pretty good, the atmosphere is big and spectacular, the sounds are good, the gameplay is challenging and fun, the engines are also nice, no game crashes or bugs. What I dislike on the engines part is the fact that the controls on this game are simply not well organized. Since it‚Äôs free, you should try it, because you have nothing to lose.

Strong PointsPretty good graphics
Good sounds
Challenging gameplay
Well-optimized engines
Well-explained tutorial
Achievements and Trading Cards
Big map, much stuff to explore
Crafting and Resources
Weak PointsControls need a serious reorganize
Sometimes music gets repetitive
Pretty hard to get used to the game
Not enough customizations
General Ratings
Graphics: 7.5/10
Atmosphere: 8/10
Audio: 8.5/10
Gameplay: 7/10
Story: N/A
Engines: 7/10

Personal Rating: 7.6/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Needs a lot of work for it to even be a comfortable pc experience, but I'll give it a positive because it is EA.

It is a small and fun game for $5 and one of those I can justify in the 'hope' that the devs are serious about this being a solid PC title.

So, as it is now, the ships arent too impressive, as they are similarly sized, the look/appearance of each is different with different attributes and bonuses/buffs and such like a character in an RPG.  There are no large capital ships to work twords right now, so we have to see what it is the development plans are to play towards long term.

Building / crafting is very rudementary and done-so with a click of a mouse after mining resources and obtaining blueprint drops.  There are modules for ships that can be simply crafted, and again the crafting system is nothing more than a one-click process right now.

The galaxy seems sizable, but have no idea about easter-eggs or value in exploration, as it doesn't seem to be there yet.  But alot of places to go, though whats the value in exploration is yet to be realized.

Perhaps long-term, building stations will be an accomplishment and add to the incentive for game-play.

This leveling system is action-oriented and not handed to you over a short period.  So playing to gain development and advancement is certain and appreciated.

I'd consider this game for some short hours of time-kill right now....its not a bad decision for $5 for me, and what I hope to see it develop into.
